data.text: @GIRLlSFIRE —feel that he wanted to be mad with his mom, for having kept this secret for so long. However, he just couldn’t. “She’s stubborn, and kind, and very pragmatic.” the list could’ve gone on, but one needed to meet their mom to really understand her fully as a person.

@GIRLlSFIRE This feeling in vincent’s only grew heavier. He had a sister. He finally.. knew who his dad was. “Mom.. she’s selfless.. more than anyone I know. Like when we’re at the shelter she’ll be the last person to eat because she makes sure everyone’s got a meal to eat.” Vince could—

@truIyvincent — You’ve got his eyes, now that I look at you.” 

“What’s, um, mom like?” Mom. That was going to take some time getting used to.

@truIyvincent — him? 

“He’s kind, thoughtful, but makes really bad jokes you can’t help but laugh at,” the girl chuckles quietly through oncoming sniffles. It was an emotional moment to say the least, finding out she had more family to love and all. “He knows everything about nothing. . . —

@truIyvincent “I don’t think dad would ever have the heart to divorce anybody.” As authoritative as he was, he was still one of the softest guys she ever knew. 

Were they ever going to tell them? If they didn’t have this one in a million chance of meeting, would she have ever known about —

@GIRLlSFIRE —actual reason why their parent separated, which only made Vince’s head go a mile a minute. “What’s your.. what’s dad like?” It made his chest heavy to ask his sister that. To finally find some answer of who his dad was.

@GIRLlSFIRE “Why would they keep this a secret from us? Do you think they got divorced?” vincent thought of the most obvious answer, but somehow it didn’t seem to fit. He stayed quiet, thinking about all the what if’s. What if their parents had stayed together? The twins didn’t know the—

@truIyvincent — Usually she’d just brush it off and pinned the reasoning on the absence of a mother, but never would she have thought it was because she had a whole other half walking around somewhere else. 

“Like, we probably have to confirm it, but I’m sure—so sure we are.”

@truIyvincent “Y-yeah,” the girl stutters, eyes locking onto the other brunette. “I guess so. . . You’re my brother, my-my twin.” It felt bizarre to hear the words exit their mouths.

For years she was perfectly fine with it being just her and her father, but at times it didn’t feel complete.—
@GIRLlSFIRE —in the picture with his twin sister. He took a deep breath, his hands in fists so tight his knuckles had begun to turn white. “You’re my sister? My twin sister?”

@GIRLlSFIRE Vince could definitely tell they were thinking the same thing but for some reason he couldn’t bring himself to say it. As long as he could remember Vincent always found it out to be just him as his mom. No one else. It made him dizzy to think that his dad was somehow still—

@truIyvincent — For years she was just fine living without a mother, and now to learn she was alive and well this whole time. . . and living with her potential brother? /Twin/ brother, if she guessed right.

“Do you think it’s true?” Her voice was hushed, as if someone else would overhear.

@truIyvincent “This is all either going to make no sense, or complete sense. . . I think we’re both thinking the same thing, Vince.” It was slowly coming together now, but she was too in shock to say it out loud. 

Her head fell into her hands, pushing her hair back with her fingers. —
@GIRLlSFIRE —my second birthday. I was born here in New York.” He looked up at Cassia, trying to ignore the feeling of throwing up.

@GIRLlSFIRE —stared aimlessly down at the desk, although his mind was racing a million miles a minute. He tried to think back of all the times his mom would be in the office on the phone with donors and most likely Cassia’s dad. Their dad. “My mom did say we had moved to Texas right before—

@GIRLlSFIRE Okay, now Vincent really needed to sit down. He plumped down into huge office chair, his hands anxiously drumming on his lap. “This doesn’t make any sense. How can we have the exact same birthday, more less the first donation date be the date of my–our second birthday.” He—
@truIyvincent — too.” After what they’d just discovered, how could she not believe him?

@truIyvincent “God, I hope not!” The brunette chortles at his question. But after these past few moments she didn’t know what to believe anymore. After delving deep to find the root of the connection between them, she didn’t expect it to go this deep.

And with his next words, her blood ran —
@GIRLlSFIRE —and just wanted to sit down. Should he bring up his nauseous and dizzy state to Cassia. Nope. If he fainted she’d figure it out.

@GIRLlSFIRE —back down at the paper’s between the two of them. “Forever..” Vince repeated Cassia, and picked up the paper with the oldest date, dating back fifteen years. “Cass, you’re not gonna believe me, but the first donation date was my second birthday.” He suddenly felt nauseous—

@GIRLlSFIRE Vince was puzzled by the fact that Cassia said her dad’s profession was in a way, a front. “Your dad isn’t like mafia is he? Money laundering?” He shook his head at the realization of what he had asked. “I watch to many movies set in New York.” He took a deep breath, and looked—
@truIyvincent — 16 years exactly from her second birthday. That’s when it all started. “. . .Forever.”

@truIyvincent — glancing up at him for some silent permission to open it up. With a nod, she slowly does so and spreads out what looked like spreadsheets dating years and years back.

“Vince, this has been going on for forever. . . Since. . .” The donation history stops at a certain year. —

@truIyvincent “I think his company deals with insurance, or something like that. It’s a legit, working thing, but also a front to help mutants, which are the majority of employees, if not all. Dad always said we can only trust each other.”

Her snooping ceased when he put down the file, —
@GIRLlSFIRE —in front of Cassia. “This folder’s labeled with my mom’s name.” His voice came out softly, the nervousness being rather obvious.

@GIRLlSFIRE —my mom’s shelter alone.” He skimmed through each drawer till he came across a folder labeled with his mother’s name, ‘Matthews, Celeste’. Vincent could feel his heart pounding in his chest. He wiped his already sweaty palms on his jeans and grabbed the folder, setting it down—

@GIRLlSFIRE —was inside. “If your dad donates a lot.. was is it exactly that he does? Or are y’all just like family rich?” Although Vincent has no intentions of sounding rude he couldn’t help but feel like the question seemed rather backhanded. “Sorry, I mean, it’s just a lot he donates to—

@GIRLlSFIRE Without a second thought he set down the office phone and began shuffling through the drawer. Pens. Paper clips. Highlighters. Bingo. A key. Vince made his way over to the filing cabinet and slid the key in. With a click, the lock gave way, giving the paid access to whatever—
@truIyvincent — coincidence. This kinda stuff is too important for it to be chance.”

@truIyvincent — to one right by her elbow. “Pretty sure that’s where he keeps a bunch of important stuff. . .” She’s thumbing through a recent folder, brows tugged in with concentration.

“Yeah, I feel it too, Vince. Like this whole thing, with us and our parents can’t just be some weird —

“I think he should have a key somewhere. Try in this drawer right here,” she gestures —

@GIRLlSFIRE —Like there’s more to this than just donations.” He picked up the office phone and began cycling through the call history in hopes of finding the number to the shelter or even his mom’s cellphone. Any clue helped.

@GIRLlSFIRE —quickly met with a strong stop. “Locked.. do you think he has a key? I could get it open without a key, but only if you want me to..” Vincent stalked over to where the desk and Cassia were. “Do you have this feeling? I have like this sinking feeling in the pit of my stomach..—

@GIRLlSFIRE Vince followed after Cassia, his attention intent on catching as much as he could from the reporter’s voice before they would be out of earshot. “Do you ever go into your dad’s office?” He interjected, and walked over to a row of filing cabinets. He pulled in a drawer, but was—
@truIyvincent — before, making a beeline for her father’s desk.

@truIyvincent — my dad’s office and figure this out for ourselves?” There was a feeling in the pit of her stomach that told her this went beyond generous donations between their parents. 

Without another word, she’s beckoning him to follow her into the room he’d wandered into just moments —

@truIyvincent Cassia glanced at the time on her phone, lips tugging into a frown, “Not for a couple of hours. He usually comes home right before dinner at five,” and her clock read just past 1 PM. 

“Maybe we shouldn’t bother them, I’m sure they’re already worried. . . We could go back to —
@GIRLlSFIRE —seen anything like this before.”

@GIRLlSFIRE —to her son. “Or when does your dad get home from work? Maybe we can talk to him first..” He met the television with a blank stare, his attention only being present enough to barely understand what was going on. “There’s always protesters outside the shelter, but I’ve never—

@GIRLlSFIRE —shelter. He just always assumed it was cheaper than previously presumed. “I can call my mom and ask?” Vince felt reluctant to offer, knowing his mom kept up with all things mutant related in the news. She would assume the worst and think something would have happened—

@GIRLlSFIRE Vince had always wondered how his mom singlehandedly always had enough money to keep the shelter going. As a kid, he didn’t know the true reality of how much it costed for every meal and bed, and necessities provided for those whose found sanctuary at the—

@GIRLlSFIRE —easily into the four and five digit numbers. Why was Cassia’s dad already donating to the shelter if she had said she would ask him to begin donating? “Cassia?” Vince yelled and  quickly got up, and began walking back to the living room, paper in hand.

@GIRLlSFIRE —one. It looked like Cassia’s dad had left in a hurry. Vince thought nothing of it until he saw the name of his mom’s shelter in fine print on top of one of the papers. Without hesitation, and any regards left for invasion of privacy, Vince skimmed over it, reading as much as he—

@GIRLlSFIRE —around but he wandered around to the desk and sat down in the chair. Way too stiff he thought. The desktop might as well have been a television. He scanned the surface of desk, taking note of how neat Cassia’s dad was. There were several folders with documents inside except for—

@truIyvincent — she’s never been this public with her powers. But she wasn’t going to stay at home either.

@truIyvincent — back to the elevator.

@GIRLlSFIRE —to say about the situation.

@GIRLlSFIRE The force field between Vincent’s hands began to shrink and expand at a rapid pace before slowly dissipating like an electric current. “We could always use more beds.. and more space for said beds. We have the ones that are constantly there, then our floaters..” he paused—

@truIyvincent — and we’ll see what he says.”

@truIyvincent — each other out.”

@truIyvincent — sure, but I think you’ve got a safer place.

@truIyvincent — jeans, glancing back and forth from her pants to her new friend.

@LlFElSAJOKE —secluded in its own way. I think it was her way of going into hiding, so to speak.”

@LlFElSAJOKE —thing or something.” He shrugged at the thought, plopping down on the couch. “I mean, at least that’s what my mom thinks. you know if you ever get the chance, you should visit to check out the shelter. You’d love it there.”

@truIyvincent — glancing at her new friend.

@truIyvincent — pull all-nighters on the roof, I’d still be staring at nothing. I’ll see the North Star or one of the Dippers if I’m lucky. . . but it’s rare.”
